p: Figure 2 b–d displays the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the synthesized materials. The TEM images of CMO_L showed a stacked structure with a d-spacing of 0.69 nm, which can be assigned to the birnnesite-type structure; the value corresponded to the interlayer distance of Mn oxides in Figure 1 . A lattice fringe derived from the buserite-type structure with a d-spacing of 0.96 nm was not observed, probably because the buserite-type structure was transformed to the birnnesite-type structure during the vacuum drying pretreatment for the TEM measurement. Additionally, CMO_T showed a bundle structure that had a d-spacing of 0.50 nm, which corresponds to half the distance in the Mn oxide tunnel framework; its rigid structure is maintained during the vacuum drying pretreatment, as described above. In contrast, CMO_S displayed lattice fringes with d-spacings of 0.47 and 0.26 nm, which can be assigned to the (111) and (311) lattice planes of the cubic spinel structure, respectively. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images in Figure S2 highlight that the CMO_T, L, and S have flake-like, flower-like, and spherical particle morphologies, respectively, and that the geometrical sizes of the particles are consistent with the TEM observations. The particle diameters of the three types of oxides are summarized in Table 1 . The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of CMOs are also highlighted in Table 1 , and it exhibited a good agreement to the geometrical size of CMOs. The BET surface areas are used to normalize the ORR and OER currents to calculate specific activities of CMOs.
